content.webTitle: Richard III review – Ralph Fiennes gets to grips with Shakespeare's ruthless ruler

fields.headline: Richard III review – Ralph Fiennes gets to grips with Shakespeare's ruthless ruler
fields.bodyText: Rupert Goold’s production begins by invoking the recent discovery of Richard III’s skeleton in a Leicester car park. Much stress is laid, in every sense, on his curved spine, which is held up to the light and which informs the physical image of Ralph Fiennes’s performance. But, although the production is based on the implied tension between the Richard of history and the one of Shakespeare’s imagination, the result is an unusually sober reading that has momentary insights but which loses something of the play’s malign wit. Shakespeare’s Richard is, above all, a consummate actor. But, although Fiennes’s dark-suited Richard compares himself to the shape-changing Proteus, he shows little delight in role-playing: he might, to all intents and purposes, be a grim-visaged banker systematically eradicating all obstacles between himself and and the top job. If there is a key to Fiennes’s interpretation, it lies in an assertive masculinity that displays a ruthless contempt for women. In the wooing of Lady Anne, Fiennes grabs her between the thighs and slaps her face. Revealingly, Fiennes gives Buckingham a stare of implacable hatred when, in their attempt to cajole the London citizens, he is playfully accused of “effeminate remorse”. And Fiennes’s Richard actually rapes Queen Elizabeth in the act of seeking her daughter’s hand. Fiennes gives us a Richard for whom people, women especially, are playthings of his perverted will. But, while this reading is psychologically consistent and executed with Fiennes’s customary skill, it sacrifices Richard’s irony and duplicity. A classic example occurs in the encounter with the young Prince Edward where the line “So wise so young, they say, do ne’er live long” is delivered to the boy’s face as a visible threat. This is a Richard who makes little attempt to mask his intentions and who, almost always, means what he says. A chilling exception comes in the moment – the best in the evening – where Fiennes, having been persuaded to accept the crown, smiles benignly at the audience and then raises a fist ominously clenched. I admired Fiennes’s Richard without ever feeling the actor enlisted us in his villainy. But he is surrounded by strong performances, especially from the women. Vanessa Redgrave’s Queen Margaret is the most surprising in that she turns this relic of the Lancastrian regime from a scolding harridan into a soft-spoken, pathetically demented figure clutching a baby doll whom she proceeds to feed from the bottle. Aislin McGuckin also registers vigorously the fire and anger of the ousted Queen Elizabeth, Susan Engel seethes with silvery horror as Richard’s mother and Joanna Vanderham turns Lady Anne into a bewildered pawn in Richard’s game. Hildegard Bechtler’s effective design is dominated by a giant crown suspended above the stage, and by skulls that accumulate on the back wall as the death count steadily rises. The play is straightforwardly presented with sharply delineated performances from Scott Handy as a meditative Clarence desperately pleading for his life, Finbar Lynch as a coldly calculating Buckingham and Mark Hadfield as both a conscience-stricken killer and one of Richard’s bureaucratic henchmen. But, while Goold’s production drives the action forward, the references to Richard’s disinterment, which bookend the evening, strike me as a red herring. The Richard of history and Shakespeare’s play are entirely different entities; and I would have liked more of the bustling energy and chameleon-like changeability of the latter whom Hazlitt, in writing of Edmund Kean’s Richard, described as “a princely hypocrite” and a born actor always conscious of his mental superiority. At the Almeida, London, until 6 August. Box office: 020-7359 4404
